LEEMORE DAFNY: What does it mean
when hospitals can't reliably
get the medications they need?

This type of market failure has
been cropping up increasingly
in the US.

But recently, several
hospital systems

took matters into
their own hands

and created a
non-profit generic drug
company called "Civica Rx."

In my class on US
health care strategy,

we explore why health
care markets fail

and the range of
possible solutions.

In the case of
inpatient generic drugs,

the contracts between
hospitals and group purchasing

organizations that
acquire the drugs

didn't provide incentives
to manufacturers

to invest in maintenance
or backup supply lines.

Hospital systems started
stockpiling drugs,
which exacerbated shortages.

We talk about how
Civica Rx solved

these problems and
welcome the board chair
to class to discuss the details.

The lessons the students
learn from this case
go beyond pharmaceuticals.

They learn to recognize market
failure and how to address it.
